author: m.kalinin
content:
> I want to add a new check in that if the second pubkey is of the form 0x0N00...00  and the first pubkey is a 0x0(N-1) validator, it will convert it into a 0x0N validator.

I am confused. Are there two different pubkeys?

author: m.kalinin
content: From what you wrote I conclude that there are two different validator pubkeys with different type of withdrawal credentials, and if the first pubkey has one type and the second pubkey has some other type then one of those validators switch to a some new withdrawal credential type? Is that correct?

author: m.kalinin
content: could you probably describe your idea with more details? I believe that to bump credential type you would just need to send a request with two equal pubkeys as it is today and then N can be turned into N+1 on the CL side e.g. 0x02 -> 0x03 -- so we basically need to add that CL part into ePBS changes. The target for consolidation requests is 1 per block today, so the fee will start growing if we have more than that. But I believe there won't be a constant load with tons of requests to update to 0x03; it is likely there will be a bunch after the fork and that's it.

author: potuz
content:
There is a single validator pubkey. Currently if your pubkey is 0x01PUBKEY and you send it twice to that contract as calldata of the form 0x01PUBKEY01PUBKEY. when we process it we change that pubkey to 0x02PUBKEY. 

We could have easily taken a different approach of having 0x01PUBKEY0200000 As the calldata needed to transform 0x01PUBKEY to 0x02PUBKEY.

author: potuz
content: What I propose is to use these semanthics to change from 0x02 to 0x03

author: potuz
content:
More generally we could always use something like the following interpretation of that calldata 0xpubkey|prefix|call|data Where |prefix|call|data| total 48 bytes and they encode any form of request that can be used in the beacon chain. this is a way of never changing the EL and being very generic as to what we can do in the CL even in the future by reserving prefixes|call combinations. 

The only caveat is that we need to first check against Electra semanthics
